Text: Stirling Castle, Statue of King Robert the Bruce on the castle esplanade

I believe Lee was a descendant of Robert the Bruce and others who fought for Scotland at Bannockburn. Limited knowledge shows me an honourable man and great leader who fought for his homeland and people. His ancestors would have been proud. He deserves his statue.
Robert the Bruce statue. Barnard castle behind him.

On this the 700th Anniversary of the Declaration of Arbroath, I give you a picture of Robert the Bruce holding the 1319 Aberdeen Feu Farm Charter. I am proud of this statue created by Alan Beattie Herriot as it was a council motion from me that led to its creation.

Robert the Bruce was crowned King of Scots on this day in 1306. The bronze statue of him was set into the outside façade in 1929 to mark the 600th anniversary of his passing. He urges you to #StayHome, stay safe and enjoy history online with us.

This bronze statue of Robert the Bruce at the Battle of Bannockburn site, had to be restored after the weather turned it green. It depicts an axe-wielding Bruce on his war horse, and was originally designed by Charles d'Orville Pilkington Jackson. @BannockburnNTS

#ThisDay 1322 - Robert the Bruce of Scotland defeated King Edward II of England at the Battle of Old Byland in Yorkshire, forcing Edward to accept Scotland's independence. There is a statue of Robert the Bruce at Lochmaben, where his family had their castle.

#HistoryThursday: this statue of Robert the Bruce was restored in 2013, and was made using the actual dimensions of Bruce's skull (discovered in 1818). The statute is at Battle of Bannockburn site, near Stirling. Article on it:

Why is the service named 1314 if it doesn’t hop off/on at @BannockburnNTS? Surely tourists would think a bus service named 1314 would take in the Battle of Bannockburn visitor centre and Robert the Bruce statue?

The hop on hop off bus is called Service 1314 but doesn’t travel to @BannockburnNTS? Where the famous 1314 Battle of Bannockburn was fought and your bus service is named after? Surely tourists to Stirling would want to visit the Robert the Bruce statue and the Visitor Centre too?
